children.html:
Throughout his career, first as a CEO of Apple, then at NEXT and Pixar, and then at Apple again, Steve Jobs has acquired a status of cult figure.
        He is probably the biggest role model for wannabe entrepreneurs across the world, and represents the archetypal fusion between business, arts and technology
        which has occurred in the Silicon Valley of the late 20th Century. He is also the perfect embodiment of the values of self-expression, genius, anticonformism, 
        which have shaped the creative economy globally.

I think part of what made the Macintosh great, was that 
        the people working on it were musicians, and poets, and artists, 
        and zoologists, and historians ... 
        who also happened to be the best computer scientists in the world. 
        [...]
        And they brought with them [...] a very "liberal arts" [...] attitude.

Your time is limited so don't waste it living someone else's life.

Don't be trapped by dogma, which is living with the result of other people's thinking.

Don't let the noise of other's opinions drown out your own inner voice.

[Steve Jobs] had a unique quality that I think is a component of genius, 
        which is the ability to connects art, you know aesthetics, beauty ... to 
        engineering, technology. He really showed what a 21st century American economy
        should be : which is connecting creativity to technology.
